total_impedance_txt: R1 and R3 connected in series so Rd=R1+R3=2Ohm
R5 and Rd connected in parallel so Rc=R5*Rd/(R5+Rd)=1.33Ohm
Rc and R4 connected in series so Rb=Rc+R4=2.33Ohm
R2 and Rb connected in series so Ra=R2+Rb=3.33Ohm

request.text: What is the voltage on R1?

solution: *** Solution by TINA assisted by AI ***
At first we calculate the total resistance between the generator nodes (IS1)
R1 and R3 connected in series so Rd=R1+R3=2Ohm
R5 and Rd connected in parallel so Rc=R5*Rd/(R5+Rd)=1.33Ohm
Rc and R4 connected in series so Rb=Rc+R4=2.33Ohm
R2 and Rb connected in series so Ra=R2+Rb=3.33Ohm
The total resistance is Ra = 3.33Ohm
Now we calculate the voltage on R1

We know that the voltage between IS1 nodes is 3.333333333333333V, because the generator current is Igen = 1A and the resistance between the generator nodes is Rtot = 3.33Ohm so the voltage between the generator nodes is Igen*Rtot = 3.333333333333333V
(1) The components R2,Rb connected in series.
(1) The voltage between this components starting and ending node is 3.33V.
(1) Rb is in the voltage divider so the voltage on Rb is Rb/Ra*3.33V = 2.33V.
(2) The components Rc,R4 connected in series.
(2) The voltage between this components starting and ending node is 2.33V.
(2) Rc is in the voltage divider so the voltage on Rc is Rc/Rb*2.33V = 1.33V.
(3) The components R5,Rd connected in parallel. The voltage on Rd is 1.33V because the voltage on Rc is 1.33V
(4) The components R1,R3 connected in series.
(4) The voltage between this components starting and ending node is 1.33V.
(4) R1 is in the voltage divider so the voltage on R1 is R1/Rd*1.33V = 667mV.
*** Passed ***: expected: 667m, got: 667m
